ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Lateral inhibition, convolutions, sharpening and blurring filters, the Fourier transform, principal component analysis, edge detection, stereo
biology background which influences computer vision practices, neural networks, etc.
machine learning, edge detection, neurons, vision
biological knowledge
Understanding the many ways of breaking down complex problems like vision, understanding biology through computational models, and vice versa.
Understanding how computers work with image data, and some hands-on practice in working with images.
How biological and artificial visual systems work
I learned a lot about numpy thats for sure
Some useful math on image processing, some idea of what part of the human visual system works, how we might attempt to model that using algorithms, etc...

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: wide range of topics, helpful psets
Weaknesses: lectures can be very fast paced

Strengths: very interesting material, do not need biology background to do well, workload is very light, professor is super chill and lectures are pretty fun, lectures were let out after 1hr and last 15 minutes were for people to ask questions if they had any, Weaknesses: professor is very passionate and will talk a lot about high level stuff, so it's sometimes hard to tell what you need to know vs what is just cool extra facts

Weaknesses: a lot of the material is super theoretical, feels unmotivated, and is covered way too fast. The exam content is a narrow subset of the material taught in class and lectures are not interesting.
Strengths: excellent lectures (very entertaining), decent homeworks. Weaknesses: not really responsible for 90% of the material; easy to just sit in class and let everything flow over your head
Strengths: psets were structured and focused, TAs were helpful. Weaknesses: lectures brushed past difficult math, could've had more OH availability.
Too biological and mathematical for a computer science student
This course presents a unique view into the topic of vision. The material moves very quickly, but it teaches many new useful bits of pure and applied math.

Strengths: Covers very interesting topics and provides opportunities through problem sets to learn the topics in detail.
Weaknesses: There is a lot of content that is discussed that is beyond the scope of the course. Besides, it is unclear to know which content is intended for undergrads and which is for grads.
A lot of interesting CV topics covered at blistering pace but very easy assignments and midterm that only requires last-minute cramming.

This course covers a lot of excellent topics which are at the core of biological and computational vision. However, there does not seem to be enough time to go through them thoroughly. The result is superficial understanding of a wide range of concepts
The lectures werent very engaging. I know the prof tried but between the heat of the room, the complex material and the late class time I think he often lost people

Interesting course with lots of material. But it might be tasking to keep up unless to set aside some time every week just to read the lecture notes. This is class can definitely use weekly small-group sections!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, but it'd be very helpful to have taken linear algebra and some probability before this class
Yes! It is a very interesting topic and helps to introduce other useful information like neural networks. The workload is fairly light, so it also is not too much of a drain on your schedule.

No. Don't do it to yourself. If you want a science credit, take another class. This is not a computer vision class--it's a computational vision class. If you want to take this course for any reason other than being genuinely interested in the material you will suffer through lectures.

I would not recommend this course. I liked Professor Zucker overall - he seems like a really nice guy and he made a real effort to connect with students and keep them engaged during lectures. However, I feel like this class is mostly comprised of lectures with a lot of complex math crammed in, without enough time to properly explain them. This ended up being pretty confusing and disengaging. I know most people take this class to get a CS elective that doubles as science credit, but I think there are much more engaging science credits out there.

Only to a student who knows a lot of advanced math (fourier series, advanced linear algebra, etc.) and computer science; the prerequisites of MATH 120 and CPSC 112 listed on the site are a complete joke -- don't just take this for the gutty science credit, it's a lot more intense than it may seem

This class is pretty cool! The professor has put a lot of craft into it and expects students to approach it with the mentality of a small seminar, so prepare for that. Problem sets were pretty simple and there weren't too many. Not having a final was also nice.

I would highly recommend it to anyone interested in the subject and has previous exposure to linear algebra, Python/MATLAB programming and working with image data. If not, I would not say it is an "easy" science credit if you are taking it for distributional requirements.

You will get a smorgsbad of topics and only acquire superficial understanding of them. The only exception is when we had to code k-means clustering algorithm by ourselves from scratch. That helped a lot. A lot of EE topics covered, like Shannon-Nyquivst sampling theorem, Fourier duality theorem, convolution impulse response, Dirac delta function, etc.
Honestly no
